author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: 'Don't Steal Possible' — 18,000 rally for better NYC schools
text:
Jeremy Bales/for New York Daily News More than 18,000 parents, kids and charter school advocates rallied at Cadman Plaza in Brooklyn to call for better schools in poor neighbors. Jeremy Bales/for New York Daily News Grammy winning singer Jennifer Hudson wowed the crowd before a massive march across the Brooklyn Bridge to City Hall. Jeremy Bales/for New York Daily News Bronx Borough President Ruben Diaz Jr., a possible future challenger to de Blasio, told the crowd he will “always be a supporter of charter schools.” Previous Next Enlarge Wearing red T-shirts emblazoned with “Don't Steal Possible,” more than 18,000 parents, kids and charter school advocates rallied at Cadman Plaza in Brooklyn Wednesday to call for better schools in poor neighbors.
“We are asking our city’s mayor and our city’s leaders to put an end to education inequality,” said Joe Herrera, of Families for Excellent Schools, a pro-charter group, which organized the rally.
Grammy winning singer Jennifer Hudson wowed the crowd before a massive march across the Brooklyn Bridge to City Hall.
BILL DE BLASIO MUST FOLLOW ANDREW CUOMO'S LEAD ON SCHOOL REFORM
Herrera and others argued the city’s failing public schools are concentrated in high poverty neighborhoods, while children in wealthier areas have access to better schools.
“We would love for the Mayor to eliminate any barriers to school choice,” said Herrera. “High quality charter schools help close the achievement gap and they are definitely part of the solution.”
Charter schools — which receive state money but are privately operated — exploded in number under Mayor Michael Bloomberg, who encouraged their growth.
Jeremy Bales/for New York Daily News Protestors march across the Brooklyn Bridge after the rally to demand equal schooling for NYC public school students. Mayor de Blasio has been less supportive of charter schools, which mostly operate without teachers unions.
CHARTER SCHOOL BOSS EVA MOSKOWITZ TO MAKE ANNOUNCEMENT 'CONCERNING HER POLITICAL PLANS'
“My son was at a public school, and every day it was hell,” said Crescentia Toney, 50 of Brooklyn. “There was no focus on discipline and learning. My son was even being bullied.”
But she said 11-year-old Jahrome has excelled since getting a coveted seat the Achievement First Endeavor Elementary School, a charter school.
A spokesman for Mayor de Blasio pointed to his recently unveiled education plan and successful implementation of Universal Pre-Kindergarten for all four-year-olds.
EXCLUSIVE: 'DREAMGIRL' JENNIFER HUDSON IN PUSH FOR CHARTER SCHOOLS
Janet Mayer / Splash News/Janet Mayer / Splash News Jennifer Hudson wowed the crowd before a massive march across the Brooklyn Bridge to City Hall. “Mayor de Blasio is focused on ensuring that every child, in every classroom, has a future that isn't limited by their zip code,” said spokesman Wiley Norvell, noting plans for universal reading support for 2nd graders; college-track coursework in algebra and computer science and additional advanced placement courses.
Bronx Borough President Ruben Diaz Jr., a possible future challenger to de Blasio, told the crowd he will “always be a supporter of charter schools.”
Officials from Families for Excellent Schools would not say how much the group paid for the event or for Hudson to perform.
A report released in June showed the group had spent more than $9.6 million on lobbying since January 2014 and another $367,000 on pro-charter school advertising.
The singer did not directly address the charter school debate during her set. But earlier in the day, she posted a photo of her visiting a class with a caption: “To Quote: my idol Whitney Houston herself! 'I believe the children are our future,' little faces full of dreams and determination! #FESdontstealpossible?"
